title: Urgent! Stored XSS at plugin's violations leading to account takeover
vulnerability_information: Hey team, I have found a stored XSS which is fired at plugin's `Violations` page. This vulnerability can be used by malicious plugin maker to **take over any account which installs this malicious plugin**. ###Vulnerability details The `Violations` page contain the following script inside its source code: ```html ... ``` The vulnerability exists because if some variable like `condition_name` contains the `` malicious value, it is injected inside the script with no escaping applied so the attacker can break legitimate script tag and plant his own malicious JS at this page. ###Steps to reproduce 0) Prerequisites: I have created a malicious plugin and published it so you can access it easily (but I didn't listed it in Plugin central to avoid the accidental installs). The plugin contains just an alert box payload. I can provide the account-takeover version if you need. The further steps are about the first malicious plugin (safe one). 1) Sign into the Plugins app with "Admin" account (victim) 2) Navigate to my malicious plugin `https://rpm.newrelic.com/accounts/{YOUR_ACCOUNT}/plugins/directory/666`. Of course, if the plugin is listed in Plugin central, there is no needed to know the direct link, the victim will see it in the plugins list and install from there. 3) Now imagine that you have installed this plugin. Since my plugin uses the plugin API, you should "install third-party software" to use it. Here it is: {F503676}. Of course, it can be regular plugin (even a one which is installed using NPI). 4) Change the license key at the script above to your own and execute it once. The plugin will appear at your account. Look for `__safe` plugin at the top panel of Plugins app. Navigate to it. Look, there are three dots after the "Database" component title, it is where the payload is hidden. 5) Now you should create some alert condition (this is a thing, the plugin is usually used for, right?). Navigate to `Alerts`, create new policy, and create a plugin condition like "some metric is less than some number at least once at 5 minutes". My plugins will send zeroes every time, so he will create the incident. {F503661} {F503663} {F503664} {F503666} 6) Navigate back to the plugin and run the script few more times. It will send zeroes and will necessarily create an incident so. 7) Wait a little and refresh the page. The Database component will become red. And a good admin should obviously check the causes of it. Click the Database component, then go to Violations. 8) Make sure the alert box is popped up. Your account could be taken over! {F503680} P.S.: Actually, all my submissions about plugins XSS can be used to take over the accounts by malicious plugin-maker. I have just understand that they can be used this way. So a high-criticality bonus will be much appreciated ðŸ˜… ## Impact The malicious plugin-maker can create infected plugin and every account of user which installs it can be taken over through the stored XSS.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hey team,

I have found a stored XSS which is fired at plugin's Violations page.
This vulnerability can be used by malicious plugin maker to take over any account which installs this malicious plugin.

Vulnerability details

The Violations page contain the following script inside its source code:

<script>
  window.violationData  = {"violation_summaries":[{"id":449673995,"account_violation_id":425146333,"account_id":2336392,"opened_at":1559817240000,"duration":164,"condition_id":10644190,"condition_term_id":77265174,"condition_name":"'\"x9fxss><img src=x9fxss></script>
...

The vulnerability exists because if some variable like condition_name contains the </script> malicious value, it is injected inside the script with no escaping applied so the attacker can break legitimate script tag and plant his own malicious JS at this page.

Steps to reproduce

0) Prerequisites: I have created a malicious plugin and published it so you can access it easily (but I didn't listed it in Plugin central to avoid the accidental installs). The plugin contains just an alert box payload. I can provide the account-takeover version if you need. The further steps are about the first malicious plugin (safe one).

1) Sign into the Plugins app with "Admin" account (victim)
2) Navigate to my malicious plugin https://rpm.newrelic.com/accounts/{YOUR_ACCOUNT}/plugins/directory/666. Of course, if the plugin is listed in Plugin central, there is no needed to know the direct link, the victim will see it in the plugins list and install from there.
3) Now imagine that you have installed this plugin. Since my plugin uses the plugin API, you should "install third-party software" to use it. Here it is: nr_new_plugin.py (F503676). Of course, it can be regular plugin (even a one which is installed using NPI).
4) Change the license key at the script above to your own and execute it once. The plugin will appear at your account. Look for __safe plugin at the top panel of Plugins app. Navigate to it. Look, there are three dots after the "Database" component title, it is where the payload is hidden.
5) Now you should create some alert condition (this is a thing, the plugin is usually used for, right?). Navigate to Alerts, create new policy, and create a plugin condition like "some metric is less than some number at least once at 5 minutes". My plugins will send zeroes every time, so he will create the incident.




6) Navigate back to the plugin and run the script few more times. It will send zeroes and will necessarily create an incident so.
7) Wait a little and refresh the page. The Database component will become red. And a good admin should obviously check the causes of it. Click the Database component, then go to Violations.
8) Make sure the alert box is popped up. Your account could be taken over!

P.S.: Actually, all my submissions about plugins XSS can be used to take over the accounts by malicious plugin-maker. I have just understand that they can be used this way. So a high-criticality bonus will be much appreciated ðŸ˜…

Impact

The malicious plugin-maker can create infected plugin and every account of user which installs it can be taken over through the stored XSS.

activities.message: Hey @skavans! Good find! I've forwarded this onto the plugins team.
activities.markdown_message: Hey @skavans! Good find! I've forwarded this onto the plugins team.

I see now that you added a new component to my plugin when reproducing the bug.

I think it is because you pushed the data for my plugin with your own custom component name "602527-reproduced". Because of this, it seems that this bug can be used also to backwards takeover the plugin-maker account. So attacker can install any plugin, send custom new component metrics to it (with payload planted in component name), and await for the plugin maker goes inside this new component to determine where it comes from. After that, the plugin-maker account could be taken over.
Thanks for your report!

activities.message: I mean that you usually pay $2500 for user-to-admin xss, where attacker can only attack his own admin. But here attacker can takeover other organizations accounts. Like here #507132, where you have added a bonus for higher impact.
activities.markdown_message: I mean that you usually pay $2500 for user-to-admin xss, where attacker can only attack his own admin. But here attacker can takeover other organizations accounts. Like here #507132, where you have added a bonus for higher impact.

activities.message:
Hey @skavans,

In the report linked, the additional bonus was explicitly stated to be attributed to our appreciation for collaborating with us, not for higher impact. This ticket fits perfectly under "Cross account access" as stated in our policy as a **High**, the other tickets have fit under "Authentication bypass" (also **High**). I hope this clarifies our decision about the bounty amount.
